pretty bland stuff in the heart of chelsea market. honestly expected more - nothing wrong with the three things we got (avocado + egg pita, falagel in pita, cauliflower) but just not that memorable / tasty - had to add salt all over the place and beg for sauce (which made things tastier but just not that interesting). Thing is, pita is easy to make - seems like they could add some neat flavors and make things more interesting.

I had the wild mushrooms sandwich. Was $12 incl. tax. For that price, I expected more. The atmosphere was cool and hip. But the portions were small. The sandwich was tasty but had a bad aftertaste. The cauliflower, which was $9, looks better and bigger. I would go for that one next time, if there is a next time.
It was good food, casual and fast. I wanted the falafel but they only have them on Tuesdays and Fridays. (Today it was a Friday but they didn't have anyway)
We bought three different sandwiches. All of them were equally tasteless and textureless. Yes, you get fried green chill-peppers on the side, but that's about it.
Best place in Chelsea Market. I love the food, the service and the drinks. You really should have the cauliflower and the mashed potatoes- amazing!!!

After reading about this restaurant in The New Yorker, I decided to give it a try. The food is outstanding and I can't wait to return. The pita bread is amazing and everything was freshly prepared. And I especially liked the cauliflower appetizer. The place was crowded but had a nice vibe. I will be back.

I love the food here!! Definitely recommend the cauliflower as it is the chef's specialty. The staff is extremely friendly and makes sure you're comfortable at the restaurant! Talea has such a great personality and really made my experience one to remember.

I was very very excited to try this - I follow them on IG and the vibe and food looks amazing. I had the steak in pita with tahini and I have to say the food it over hyped. It was okay and I've definitely had better. The servers are friendly and the food comes out quickly - but I was disappointed with the quality of beef. There was too many layers of fat in my sandwich- maybe it was a one time thing. I'm considering giving this another shot and reformulate my opinion.
Not much of a gyro fan but I tasted this and I couldn't get enough! I had the minute steak. Pretty good!

I love the sandwich I got: the slow cooked beef. Â But it was not worth the bad service and the long wait I received while waiting to pick up my order. Â The kid behind the counter kept giving me the wrong change and was rude to patrons. Â Never again!
Holy cow you have to try this place! My husband declared his folded hamburger the best sandwich he's ever eaten. I LOVED the ratatouille with tahini and hard boiled egg. Unbelievable pitas too!
The cauliflower was out of this world. You've never tasted cauliflower like this before. And the pita with lamb kebab was really tasty. The make the food right in front of you. Nice vibe.
Amazing place and atmosphere. First tried folded cheeseburger and the taste was amazing then same day I came back for kebab. The food is really good there.

Fantastic. Â Very friendly staff!! Â  No attitude when just ordering tap water. Â  We shared a pita stuffed with amazing mushrooms, asparagus and other greens. Â  The pita itself was light and fluffy - great!! Â  We will be back.
Best pita in the city!!! Amazing service and great vibes. Must try the cauliflower and the run-over potato.

OK, we just had the cauliflower - as we were intrigued by the name on the menu. It's a tough competition with the cauliflower my mom used to make (I'll just say there wasn't much left, if I got to it before it was served). So leaving all memories on the side - this was indeed great - and Â the famous is for a great reason. It's hard to describe, but it's so soft, yet crispy on the outside. It's so pretty - that you kind of feel sorry for ruining it once you dig in.
Amazing food and atmosphere! Can't wait to come back! Loved the stew pita and the vegetarian options. I wish there were more places like this one!

One of my favorite things about mushrooms is how much flavor can be packed into them. So what did I just pay $11.50 for? A remarkably pillowy pita? That's a start. A half filled sandwich? Can't be. Underseasoned mushrooms? Nope. A little sour cream and raw spring onion? You see where I'm gong here. I love the idea of serving every sandwich, even if its underwhelming, with a full fried hot pepper, but finding 3 grains of sea salt on it only left me wondering why that too had been so poorly seasoned. And, I guess it's cool to sit and eat a middling sandwich amongst a throng of cooks shouting at the top of their lungs, but it's cooler when the food makes it worth it. Had I not noticed the schug condiment sitting by the waiter station I wouldn't have known about my one option for adding a little more flavor to my sandwich. My waiter certainly didn't offer it up. Or a fork, for that matter. As a long-time New York eater I love when someone comes in with a new way to eat on a pita, even if it's not that new. But Miznon is just charging tourists $11.50 for a stand in for the real thing. For $11.50 in NYC I'm used to getting a drippy, crunchy, salty, spicy, pickly mess of a pita Â that fills me up for hours. I'd definitely try the world-famous cauliflower if it weren't called world-famous and look like the same cauliflower I've made at home by putting it in a hot oven, then taking it out.
the food here is great. creative in presentation and high in quality. added points for the staff who are energetic and eager to help you have a great meal

I tried to schedule a team event here and had a miserable experience. I went to the location twice. The first time I spoke with the tall man who runs the operation, he was helpful and assured me that the event sounds feasible. I went back one week before the proposed date to finalize the menu. Again I was assured everything was set, at this time I also I interacted with the other man who runs the location. He was shorter with curly hair. He was not easy to talk with and was always on his phone. He also said we are all set. The date of the event, I went down to confirm seating before bringing the team, at this point the curly hair man tells me that they have a private event and that he doesn't know what I'm talking about. We found another location nearby, but the lack of organization and miserable attitude of the second head of the location will guarantee I don't come or plan anything here in the future.
delicious food, great service, fun ambience

Walked in on a Friday night, put name down around 9:30pm and was texted for an available table about 15-30min after. It was still very good vibes at this hour! The food was great (ragu papardelle was phenomenal, lemon chicken was tender). The honey ricotta appetizer was sooo good (ask for extra honey) and the lemon cheesecake to finish was perfect. It was not too sweet and was the right balance to end the savory meal. Will say only the espresso martini was quite mid. It is on the third floor of Columbus circle, and take the elevator on the side of the first floor to avoid having to switch escalators every floor. Highly recommend!

I cannot explain how special this place is. You can really come here for any occasion; date, taking the parents out, GNO, etc. Service was impeccable; Khalil and Juan were great, we felt spoiled with attention. Now to the menu, everything we had was great. The breads are both amazing but then we were so full towards the end of the meal so I'd only choose one and then come back for the other one. My friends liked the 'Roni cups but I would've liked to save room in my tummy for other things. The Filetto was my favorite dish and worth the hype. Save room for dessert and at least get the Lemon Cheesecake, another worth it dish. The sorbetto was a great palate cleanser to close out the meal. And cocktails, trust your server and get any of the spritzes (also served in cute glasses) but the orange wine we had was pretty spectacular. Bottom line, this place is a great new addition to the NYC food scene, not cheap, but worth it. I already can't wait to go back.

Aesthetically pleasing restaurant with great service, ambiance, and food! The cocktails were great and every dish tasted amazing. Getting a reservation is difficult but would definitely recommend trying the food here!
Good good and vibe! Tough to get a reservation right now. And they don't serve the full menu at the bar yet (which is why I wasn't sold at 5 out of 5 stars). But all in all, I'd come back!

Bad Roman has finally opened in the old Landmarc space in the Deutsche Bank Center. It was certainly worth the wait. The space is beautiful. The vibe and playlist are just as awesome. The crowd looks to be appropriately upscale and trendy. But you don't come to Bad Roman for any of those great things, you come for the absolutely amazing and creative food. Everything we ate was delicious. The cocktails were wonderful as well. Leave room for dessert since the Lemon Cheesecake is as delicious as it is beautiful and unique. Make your reservations now, while you can. Clearly the best new restaurant of the year.

This was excellent. We went with a group of four and ordered a crazy amount of food, with the musts for next time being the garlic babka, roni cups, the wedge, the rigatoni, and (surprisingly) the short rib pappardelle. The rock shrimp garganelli was excellent too, and the table was split on the gricia -- I thought it was a little more peppery than I'd typically want from this kind of dish, but my wife really loved it. We were really excited about the tiramisu ice cream cake, and it was very good, but I'd love to try their other desserts next time. This was way too much food and I felt sick at the end, but it was all really great.

This place is a scene and a refreshingly fun one in Time Warner Center. Â Harrison our server was the best waiter I've encountered in a very long time. Â The drinks were fabulous and the shrimp garganelli was so satisfying, filling and flavorful. Â The lemon cheesecake is an absolute must.
Some of best food I have ever had!! So many great options! Â The decor and music were a huge hit as well. Â Service was excellent- sommelier knew her stuff!! 5 stars all around!

The decor, the food, the presentation! These are just a few exciting things about Bad Roman. I was lucky enough to snag a seat at the bar at this delicious hot spot. An absolute must is the lemon cheesecake and yes I realize that I am jumping to dessert but it was just THAT GOOD! I had the filet topped with cacio e pepe ravioli. My only critique? I wish I had ordered two! We also got the short rib pasta (freshly made!) and it was light and delicious. Service was great. Skip the tiramisu ice cream cake unless you have coffee and can stand to let the dessert melt for 10 min so the ice cream can get a little soft.

Had dinner with a friend last minute a month ago. The restaurant is absolutely stunning. Beautiful design that makes you feel you are in an elegant but whimsical hip great aunt's home. Views of the Columbus Circle and the park add an added layer. The host made room for us with no reservation advising us we couldn't linger which was fine with us. The food was absolutely delicious - incredibly flavorful and satisfaction in every bite. I will definitely return.

The atmosphere was great! A really nice place to come after work or for a nice dinner. It was perfect for a girls night. All the food we had was very good but the dishes that stood out were the scallops, pepperoni cups and the garlic babka bread! Mo, our waiter was really nice too.

My third visit and it gets better every time. The place is beautiful and the food delicious. The cocktails are fun and campy. Everything has a fun twist of whimsy but don't let that fool you the culinary chops are serous. Shawna was my server twice. She is a superstar! She knows her menu, describing and recommending items like a pro. Shawna just make the experience that much better. Must get are the garlic babka and the lemon cheesecake, yes those lemons are actually cheesecake. Bad Roman has made dining fun again. From the hosts in front the servers Bad Roman is an amazing experience.
The food and service were fantastic. The location was bigger than I expected. Â I will definitely return.

Tried the new hype spot and it was great - line out of the door to get in so a reservation is a must. We loved the shrimp pasta, pepperoni cups, and the dessert - we also got the broccoli as a side and it was delicious. Don't forget to order a race car shot to kick off your meal.

OMG! Thank god we got a res when we did because this place is blowing up on social media! Seriously every other Instagram post and TikTok video is about Bad Roman! To start the ambiance - it is in the time Werner center which has so many other great restaurants as well. It is defiantly a different feel entering from a mall setting versus the street like many other restaurants in NYC, but it reminds me of restaurants in the big hotels in Vegas in that sense. The interior is STUNNING every last detail was thought of - from the women's bathroom to the hall to the wallpaper on the ceiling and I can't forget to mention the incredibly comfy chairs. We had an 8:30 res and weren't seated until 8:45 and our waiter never formally introduced himself so that was a little confusing but we went within the first two weeks of opening so I'll make an exception. Everyone was incredibly friendly and insightful when we asked about recommendations from the menu. They also apologized over and over for the wait. Now for the FOOD and DRINK. Cocktails looked unreal but we were in the mood for wine and the wine list was so impressive and extensive. For food we had the whipped ricotta with truffle honey and focaccia, the roni cups, the spicy caeser, the short rib pasta and the filet with cacio e pepe raviolo. It was GREAT! The roni cups while expensive for what they were were so delish and very unique. The filet with the raviolo stole the show for me, the steak was amazing and I loved the cacio with it. YUM YUM YUM. Everything was great and I will def try to go back soon.

Love the design of the restaurant. I love the food and ambiance there. The design is really cool. The only downside is that probably cuz we went during their second week of opening, the servers still got lost from time to time and it took a long time for things to get served. There were also some miscommunications among waiters so duplicate items were brought.
The banker and ricotta were excellent. Â All our pasta dishes (chicken and parpadelle) were tasty and the lemon cheesecake dessert is a must order - service was good and it was reasonably priced

Was lucky enough to snag a reservation at Bad Roman right within there first couple weeks opening. They did an excellent job decorating this restaurant, while all of the quality branded restaurants are beautiful this one is really exceptionally done. The food was also incredible. The garlic babka is a must order. So so good no matter what else you are getting. We also order Hamachi crudo whenever it is on any menu, and this one still somehow exceeded expectations. The spicy Cesar was good, the same as you can get at quality bistro which in our opinion is a top salad in NYC. The lobster pasta was good, the highlight definitely being the lobster over the pasta. The pasta wasn't the best I've had but the lobster was cooked perfectly and thy crack it in a way that's easy to eat without the grandness of the presentation being reduced. We aren't usually dessert people but the chocolate tarte with olive oil gelato sounded too good to turn down, and I'm so glad we got it. It was almost like a thick pudding with the most strangely delicious olive oil creamy gelato. We would likely get all of this again, although would try a different pasta and entree next time. Very impressed with bad Roman so early in their being around. We can't wait to come back!

YUM! The vibes were amazing along with the food. An interesting menu with dishes I have never seen before, definitely an experience and a hard reservation to come by. The staff were nice and attentive as much as they could be with the restaurant being very busy. Loved everything about bad Roman!

This is the best new spot in NYC. Make sure you make reservations ahead of time because it fills up. Even though it is so busy, they still sat us on time. We got there early and had some drinks in the bar. The service was great. The service at the table was even better. I highly suggest the pepperoni cups, the honey ricotta, the prime rib meatballs, the sausage and pep bread, the filet and the lobster. The lemon cheesecake is great. I look forward to going back.
Decent food / drinks, good service, cool ambience but both of us got food poisoning after. I get that tt happens but obviously that tainted the experience :'(
Waited an hour for bar seats and bartender waved his friends over for them as we were about to sit down. Sure the food is great, couldn't Â find out.
The food was very bad, despite having a nice ambiance in the restaurant. Everything was extremely salty and not cooked well, even simple pastas. I will definitely not be going back.

They are generous with their portions for their prices. The pieces of fish and rolls are a good size. The staff is also so sweet. Convenient location so you can avoid delivery fees by picking up directly. An excellent take out option for the neighborhood!

I was initially hesitant to try this place based on location, but was convinced by positive reviews online and they were not wrong! This is the best takeout sushi I've had so far in Brooklyn heights. Way better quality/freshness of fish than nearby iron chef house or ozu. The photo speaks for itself. I'll only be going to sushi gallery for takeout from now on!!! Highly recommend!
The best place for sushi in Brooklyn hands down! Provides great value for a good price!
Really delicious hand rolls and specialty rolls, and the owners are wonderful people.
It's a really small restaurant, and might be easy to overlook, but the sushi is fantastic! Great quality, great value, and really great owners. Definitely worth it.
Great place for sushi take-out! Sushi tastes fresh and they make the food very quickly. Prices are also very fair.
This keeps happening to me whenever I'm craving sushi! Sushi Gallery is CLOSED until 10/28... just an FYI so you don't have to make the trip here like we did!

I love Sushi Gallery! This is honestly the best sushi I've ever had. We lived right next to sushi gallery for about 2 years and would get it at least once a week. They have a refrigerator outside the restaurant so you can grab and go on your way home (Not sure if this is still there during COVID). The menu has a lot of options. Everything I have tried there has been great. Their tea is wonderful and their soups are the best I've had as well. It takes a bit of time to get your food because it is just the husband and wife making it. They make everything right in front of you. They are extremely hard working. At first they come off as very straight forward and to the point but once you get to know them they are very friendly. We moved from Brooklyn right before COVID and we have not been able to find a sushi spot as great as sushi gallery. Every time we go back to the city we make a point to stop by here. When we last visited they remembered us and were so glad we came back. They were telling other guests how we used to live nearby and come eat all the time.

During the pandemic, the Sushi Gallery operates as take-out only. Â At about 4:15 p.m. Monday through Saturday, the two owners make sushi and have it ready for pickup. Â However, ask instead to have sushi made fresh. Â Sushi should be consumed within a half-hour after receiving it for the delightful, fresh taste. Â Eel-avocado particularly comes out nice and warm.

Excellent sushi! If you are a raw sushi fan get the galleria roll it's just amazing, if you are a tempura sushi fan get the shrimp tempura one. Just amazing! Cozy place! Good attention! Definitely coming back!
I love the sushi from this restaurant! I've tried a bunch of different menu items and they've all been delicious, especially the spicy tuna roll. The service was also very fast.

Sushi Gallery had closed during the pandemic but has now reopened. If you want sushi in the Brooklyn Heights/Clark St. area and don't mind getting takeout, this is the best quality option. Â Since they don't have the resources to provide outdoor seating, they've put in place a temporary $10 minimum and require a credit card for payment. They also suggest that you call ahead to place your order, but it's not required. My expectation is that once it's safe to return to normal business practices they will return to in-house restaurant service. For now, these are the limitations the owners have put in place to keep themselves and you safe.

This sushi place is located within the 2 train Clark St Station. I was pleased to find out it was more of mom and pop place run by a couple. I ordered the salmon avocado and eel avocado. They both came out in great portions with fresh ingredients, simply delicious. The rice was soft but not too chewy. Direct and prompt service. Ended up ordering another round of eel avocado. 3 rounds of rolls came out at $16. Very affordable. Would certainly return to the area when in the mood for sushi. At least I won't need to go outside in the cold.

Placed a delivery order via Postmates, and I am very disappointed. Ordered a Gyoza, a Vulcano Roll, and a Fireball Roll which did not look anything like the photos on Yelp. The food was super spicy and the rolls was broken and smushed. Never again.

I wanted to like this place, I really did. Â I'm local and would love to add another sushi restaurant to my "go-to's" so I convinced a friend to try Sushi Gallery with me for take-out. Â My major issue (my friend noticed it to) was that the sushi rice had a slight soapy taste to it. Â Yes, soap, as if maybe they didn't rinse the rice pot fully after they cleaned it. Â I ordered the sweet potato roll and was just expecting sweet potato but got a roll with avocado, sweet potato, and sauce, and the sweet potato had a grainy texture to it. Â The additional items on the sweet potato roll weren't bad, but given that it was in part for my kids, they made it inedible to them. Â I ordered directly from the restaurant and had a hard time finding a menu, but the one I found didn't provide a description other than "sweet potato" so I just wish it was more descriptive. Â The spicy crunchy tuna roll had what looked like balls of rice crispy cereal on top, and I'm used to the more shredded fried crisps. Â They also didn't include the small cups to put soy sauce in, and since I was eating my meal outside it made it more difficult than if I was home I would've had a dipping bowl. Â But I'm not a fan of plastic waste so I can't get too mad at them, but it was bad timing. Â The wasabi was melted and fully touching the rolls near it in the container, which again for me wasn't a big deal, but made it so that my kids they wouldn't eat those rolls. Â Also worth noting that they add 3.99% if you pay with credit card (the prices listed are if you pay in cash). Â They didn't have bulgogi (they said they only have sushi) but maybe that's a covid thing? Â Maybe I'll give them one more chance but based on my first visit, I'm not very hopeful unfortunately.
The best sushi I have ever tasted! It was fresh, flavorful, and great texture. The staff was so friendly and attentive, Â and no wait to be seated!

Specifically came here because all of the great reviews on Yelp and it did not disappoint. I've been searching for a good sushi place in NY and I've finally found it. Very affordable and great quality. The only downside is that they don't take reservations and there is a limited amount of tables so plan accordingly. Can't wait to go back!
Tiny shop near the Subway but some of the best sushi I've ever had and at incredibly low prices. They prefer cash, but take cards for tabs over $10. The Hamachi Don is a particular favorite.

First time going and I loved it! I ordered to-go but the staff was so nice and friendly! Didn't have to wait too long and the food was super good!! Prices were great too and there was a huge variety of rolls which I loved. Literally ate it all in 2 seconds. Might be my new favorite sushi place.

my sis has always raved about this gem.... and once again, she did not lead me astray! reasonably priced sushi made with fresh fish and generous portions. seems to be a mom and pop operation as well. for so many years, i went to miso in dumbo....i declare that sushi gallery is the new official go-to sush spot when I'm in town!

Mom and Pop sushi place that's really good. Â Everything we had was so yummy, can't remember the last time that happened. Udon noodle soup was flavorful and full of veggies, spicy tuna and Â Spicy Tuna, Yellowtail & Salmon Roll were perfect. Â They also have all this sushi ready to go in their case no waiting. Â This place is kinda small but don't let that put you off.

This is a perfect sushi place. A lovely young at heart couple runs the restaurant. They prepare their food with love. The sashimi pieces are fresh and at perfect temperature. It is worth a trip from Manhattan (subway line 2)

Best sushi in the neighborhood. A true hidden gem, Sushi Gallery resides in the Clark Street 2/3 subway station. In addition to delicious sushi, they have the best rice, the most delicious seaweed salad, and most amazing Japanese drink selection. But my favorite thing of all is their ginger. Whatever they do to it makes it the perfect and most delicious palate cleanser. Â Nothing better than a spicy salmon roll followed by it. The best. Â I love you Sushi Gallery. You complete me.

Lovely meal at Sushi Gallery. If this were our local, we'd be thrilled. Nice rolls, good portions, excellent service...I'm giving this 5 stars as a perfect place for takeout sushi or a quick sushi dinner. Not a date night or fancy high end sushi experience - there are other places for that. This, however, really hit the spot for exactly what it is: a lovely neighborhood sushi bar.

Best Sushi in the area, hands down! Reasonable prices and always incredibly fresh fish! Husband and wife that run the restaurant are adorable and so friendly. Definitely recommend, especially the yellowtail, it is so good!

Was pleasantly surprised by this place... We ordered for pick up late on a Tuesday night, and the staff stayed until we arrived, which ended up being at least 15 min past the closing time. Not to mention, the sushi is delicious, served in large portions, and is extremely affordable.

My favorite sushi place in Brooklyn! Great prices and quality is superb. Small little spot run by two kind people who know how to make amazing food! Love it so much I visit often enough that they know my order without question. I recommend this spot to anyone visiting downtown Brooklyn!
Last Update: BEST PLACE TO GO FOR SOJU BOTTLES. But actually. What would normally cost $18 in Koreatown is only $10 here (and bigger!).

Outstanding sushi spot despite being located in the Clark st subway station. The price is spot on and the service is friendly, quick and efficient. They also have some pretty good sushi to go options which makes this my go to when I'm coming home late from work.

This was one of our orders of sushi! This place is amazing, the sushi was delectable! It's so good, my bf in the background couldn't keep his chopsticks out of my plate :-). Try it for yourself, fantastic!
Owners are nice and respectful. Every roll I've had has been great. Â Lots of bang for your buck. Definitely visit!

A lovely, adorable spot for sushi! A great atmosphere for a small restaurant located so conveniently in the Clark St. Subway station. The sashimi and sushi combo was a perfect size with just the right assortment of fish types and good pairing roll pairing. Will definitely be gokng back for more!

My friend took me here the other day. This has been her sushi spot since she moved into this neighborhood. It felt cozy and the food was good. I love that it's a mom-and-pop business. I would definitely return.

Can't believe I lived right by here and ignored this place for as long as I did. Total mom & pop operation with a lotta love going into the food. I always get it to go but their spicy scallop roll is the best I've ever had. The portions are nice and the fish is fresh. Don't sleep on this place!

Our go to for sushi due to awesome quality and price. Â The usual we get is the spicy combo, which has more of a kick than other spots. Â While it is a small restaurant with a half dozen or so tables and bar seating, we have never experienced a wait. Â A great mom and pop operation that works like clockwork as shown by their attentive service.

I'm literally writing this review while I'm here.... it is SO GOOD. Let me start with- I worked at one of the top sushi restaurants in Los Angeles for 6 years as a server then a bar tender. Rarely do I write reviews and especially about sushi spots. I would put their fish up against the best. Honestly, the environment of many sushi places can make you think it's better than it is. This place might be in a subway, but it is worth it. If you are considering it, DO IT. Just FYI- I ordered salmon & eel sushi, spicy tuna roll and the volcano roll. Super happy
Hardworking couple. Decent sushi. Nothing to write home about. But definitely stick to the sushi. Gyoza is microwaved. Udon was overcooked.
The sushi/sashimi dance was phenomenal and the spicy combo was really great too. Highly highly recommend, reasonably priced... wish they had uni!
Delicious sushi rolls. Huge, creative, and lots of fish in them. My favorite is the Explosion Roll. Adorable presentation. Relatively inexpensive too. The best sushi in the neighborhood.
Can't believe we only JUST found this place! It's my new favorite spot. Kind, quaint, great food and even better prices. Highly recommend this mom and pop hideaway.

I have been eating at sushi gallery for about 10 years now .. by far the best sushi around .. humble husband and wife duo make incredible fresh and delicious sushi ! I come so often I sit down and they already know my order by heart .. don't let the subway vibe fool you this place is awesome !

their rice bowl with sashimi - hwedupbap - is sooo good. their hot tea and miso soup top it off for a great lunch. It's fresh and savory at the same time. the place is run by a couple, they know what they're doing and they're good at it!

A hidden gem. Came here two days ago for lunch and returned tonight for dinner. Be prepared to wait a little bit if it's busy, because it's a literal mom and pop restaurant in which an adorable Asian couple does allll the food prep/serving/etc. The miso soup was delicious to start, and the woman serving was attentive (when we came, we were the only ones here). I ordered the spicy tuna roll and the East River roll. Both were amazing. Really worth it for the price you pay. Definitely plan to become a regular!

Mom and Pop sushi spot. Â I love it here. really fresh, great prices. Â They have black rice, which is high in protein which is fun to test out. Â I had a black rice kimchi roll (owners are Korean) which was a cool snack. Â These guys kill, I wish they were closer to Cobble Hill.

Best Sushi in Brooklyn Heights... Â Don't let the location turn you away (Clark Street subway station 2/3 line). A favorite of ours for take out. Â If you don't live in the area - it's fine for dining in. Â The decor is simple.

So comfortable and cozy inside. Love this place. Â Very fresh and inexpensive a great place to pop in for a little taste of fish at a good price. Â The fair pricing doesn't mean this place is mediocre, it is quite good.

It was just ok . Based on the reviews I was expecting a bit better . The sushi left me with a heavy feeling and a bit of bellyache . The rice was so mushy, their green tea tasteless , miso soup did not taste fresh and so much mayo and sauces on all the sushi ... nope , although very convenient ...this is not a traditional sushi house but ready a pit stop for students who wants to stuff their tummy with cheap sushi .

Quite dissapointing, considering the high reviews. Everything was big, and reasonably priced for NYC, but Everything tasted bland and boring. We started of with some apps, which were all mediocre. We also ordered a few sushi roll combos, and a Korean rice and sashimi bowl. The rolls were alright, but the Korean bowl was poor, with bland rice, and strange warm lettuce. Additionally, there were fake crab sticks; never a good sign of a sushi restaurant. Service was fine for new york, we had to get our own soy sauce, and interactions were brief, but our server proactively split checks. 2.5 but I'll bump to 3.
Besides service being slow because only 2 people working it was sooooo good!!! Small place but great quality! And for the price, even better. Highly recommend explosion and volcano roll
Definetely the best sushi I have had in a while.!! All the fish is fresh and the staff is amazing!!! This place is a must come if you are around the area!! Yum

Love this unpretentious mom and pop shop! No Mexican making sushi or deliver take outs just this lovely old Korean couple. Food is good, not the best but the owners and the atmosphere deserves a 5! A classic nostalgic family business you see in some Japanese movie in a small town. So rare to see in NY!

Hands down our favorite sushi. We are regulars! Love to support a local mom and pop (quite literally!) - the duo that run Sushi Gallery are truly lovely. Expect meaty, delicious, great-value-for-your-sushi-buck. They also offer black rice which is healthier and delish. 5 gold stars for our favorite spot!
Favorite sushi spot to eat in Brooklyn. Run by a wife and husband. Sushi is always very fresh and the service is fantastic.

My go-to place for Hwe-Dup-Bap (sushi rice bowl?). It may take a little while for your order to come out, but its reliable, local, and good. I'd pick this place over the other "sushi" places on the same block. Owners are great and if you're a regular, they will remember your order. I'm a fan.

Sushi joint inside a busy subway station? Â While that may deter you from going in, stop thinking that nonsense! Good things happen when you least expect it.we need to support more of these mom and pop shops. The couple is so friendly and welcoming. Â What's awesome is that if you're on the go, they have some pre packaged sushi for you to pick up. Price is really reasonable. Spicy tuna/salmon roll for 5 bucks? Bingo. Sushi is fresh and simple. Sure they have the assorted special rolls but if you want something simple as you hustle and bustle on your way in or out of the subway, this place is zen. Yes, I just equated biting into a spicy salmon roll as zen. ::cue the gong::

Lovingly nicknamed "Subway Sushi" this is on of our favorite spots. Reasonably priced. Delicious food (Henry and Clark Rolls are great). When you eat raw food you don't want to mess with a place that keep their place clean...so Most importantly thing is they are IMMACULATELY CLEAN! From the bathroom to when you walk out the door..Clean! Look at their history of cleanliness ratings from the health inspector and they have basically every Brooklyn sushi place beat. They are a sweet couple that are there day in and day out. Also a good take-out sushi spot for a lunch on the go!

Absolutely delicious! Fresh, large portions and inexpensively priced. This place is not as fancy as the neighboring sushi establishments but tastes much better. It's not about the decor and pretentious atmosphere; it's all about the food!

Yay!! Found another hidden gem in Brooklyn Heights near Promenade. Loved their volcano roll and explosion roll. It was my second time eating sushi rolls in my life and I got to enjoy eating it more. Will visit again:

I absolutely love this place. It is a small intimate restuarant connected to the train station but makes the best sushi. I have been going to this place for 4 years. I always bring out of town guests and they love it.
Great fish quality and intimate, unpretentious setting. Shame they dont deliver but they have a take out window!

This place is fantastic. I'm a sushi fanatic and good quality sushi is something I obsess over. This is a small mom and pop shop that serves excellent sushi. I've lived in Brooklyn Heights for three years and this is THE place for sushi. Very reasonable prices. I frequent this place constantly and must have eaten here over twenty times. The sushi was excellent each time and I have nothing to complain about. Give it a try, you will not be disappointed!

Honestly at first I was apprehensive about going. But after being taken there it's going to be my go to spot in the area. Very good sushi, nice place, no frills but authentic. And great price. 10/10 would recommend.

The best sushi in Brooklyn Heights. The owners are super nice. And they have ready made take home rolls, super yummy and affordable. Dinners are the easiest when I pick up several on the way home from work.

Sooooooo fresh. I read some comments about ppl complaining about this place not being gourmet enough. But they have the best rice in town! Everywhere I would get this hard cold rice that you can't digest well. If you put ready made sushi in the fridge they normally become so stiff. At sushi gallery the rice is sooo soft, you could taste how much ingredients they put in the sushi. Seriously they are not salty with the amount of ingredients. The rice stayed soft,(not as soft as when it was made), even after putting the fridge over night. The only downside is that it opens at three. cuz I want to eat more!!!!!!!!!
Awful. I walked in and felt like I had just walked into someone else's hotel room by mistake. Â They didn't say a work to me. Â No joke. Â The weirdest experience ever. Â I walked out!!!
Good sushi, a little quiet and chill. Might be too quiet for a date, but food was top shelf.

Sake for sake and won for won the best and greatest sushi deal. You'll feel like baddest mammer jammer Dolemite after getting a bottle of cold sake for $4 and some of the freshest sashimi for $10 that includes a maki. Â I never roll out of here anything less than satisfied.

AMAZING! When I moved to Brooklyn a friend of mine recommended this spot and I was a bit skeptical with it being in the subway station, however, this is the best sushi I have found since moving to the city. They owners are fast, sweet and the rolls are delicious! I will most certainly hitting this place for lunch after I move.
The sushi is cheap compared to the other sushi restaurants on the corner (there are three) and bonus it's also way better quality.
The best sushi place in Brooklyn Heights! Â Sushi is fresh and delicious. Â The service is warm and inviting every time. Prices are very reasonable!

The reviews didn't lie. This is a great place to get some sushi. Family owned and very small but cozy. I always feel awkward eating in places like this but they never neglected me nor bothered me. I got two rolls Alaska and Spicy Salmon and they were HUGE! For a tall guy who eats a lot the sushi pieces were big enough to fill me. If you've ever encountered the problem of a sushi meal not satisfying you a ten dollar tab will fill you up and you will be willing to pay more. Very affordable and a great way to have a good meal. Will start eating there regularly. Eat here!
Pretty nice place. Interesting, well balanced rolls. Good sashimi. A good value (which from me is high praise.) Cozy atmosphere.

I stayed at the St George dorms when I was in college and every Tuesday, a whole group of my friends and i would come here! Â A few years later, I moved down the block with some friends we still came here, this place always had us coming back. It's small and very intimate which is great! And plus, their spicy tuna is OUT OF CONTROL! It's SO spicy!! It hits the spot!! If you're in the area, or want great sushi for a good price, try this place!
Poor decoration, warm room, cheap fish, there was even bones in my fish, the rice was overcooked and the service was awful + unfriendly. Run away!
Really like the quiet and quaint atmosphere. Spicy tuna and California were my favorite rolls. Fire cracker roll was too much cream sauce spread on it.

I've lived in the Heights for a little over 2 years and only recently discovered this gem. Â Frankly, I avoided this place like the plague as I mistakenly assumed that anything connected to a subway station was infested with the cooties. Â But one evening, perhaps feeling emboldened by the NYCDOH "A" stamp of approval, I went in and ordered a yellow tail handroll, salmon skin roll and salmon roll. Â  I was seriously blown away by the fresh taste and quality of their fish. Â Since then I have been ordering take out from them weekly.

this out-of-sight sushi place not to call it a restaurant since it does not have the strong scent of a restaurant, serves one of the freshest sushis in town in a cosy atmosphere. Not a top-class one, but never lets you down for what you pay.

When I called to order around 5pm, they are out of what I want. I choose an alternative, out of that too. Voice message says they're open from 1-7pm everyday, called at one, they tell me they open at 2pm.

I have no idea why this place has so many stars. Friendly service and that's about where it ends. I got the 3 roll spicy combo that comes with tuna salmon and crab. Well I couldn't tell what roll was what because there was 10 pounds of spicy mayo slobbered all over it and that's all I could taste. Unless your one of those people that pours a bottle of hot sauce on ever thing u eat avoid this place at all costs....

I can't say much because I've only been here once, but the bibimbap is outstanding...addictive, even. Very reasonably priced. Tiny place, only a few tables, very nice staff. Clean and quiet. Looks like a mom and pop shop. It's NOT in the subway, it's at ground level.

A hole in the wall with great sushi that is incredibly fresh and the mom and pop service from Mr. and Mrs. Cho are tops. We had a phenomenal meal there particularly some of the eel-spicy tuna and shrimp tempura combinations. So its near the subway, this is New York not Peoria so what's the big deal if the food and service are first rate.

So my boyfriend and I decided to eat here one night and I am glad that we did. This is a mom and pop sushi restaurant so the service is a little slow, but the sushi is super yummy and the staff is very nice. Go!

Had lunch here another day and came out more then satisfied. From outside place doesn't look like much as a matter of fact it doesn't look like much inside either but u just have to give it a try. Its run by a very nice couple, attentive and polite. Its a small place about 5 tables and few bar stools however the menu is pretty extensive. From simple sashimi to lots of special rolls. I had a mushroom soup that was soo flavorful it felt that they just picked them from the forest. Its not a fancy place, just a place to come and eat fresh, tasty food.

Family owned, super fresh sushi and great service, not like that piece of crap restaurant across the street. They barely speak english yet have never gotten my order wrong. how is that possible! love sushi gallery for affordable fresh sushi in brooklyn!

The sushi here is really good and always tastes fresh. The lunch specials are also a really great deal. Healthy, tasty food at an affordable price is a definite must visit in my book. Location is rather secluded but if your goal is not about the dining experience then check it out.

Best sushi in NY! We lived in the Brooklyn Heights for 3 yrs and went to Sushi Gallery every week. Everything is fresh and the miso soup is the best I tried. The best part are the owners, such great people. They make you feel welcomed every time. Sonya and Quan, if you read this: Alex and Nadia wish you all the best!
Best sushi in Brooklyn Heights. Â Service is great, it's never too crowded and the food is delicious!

What a hidden gem in NYC. Â The reviews were appealing so I decided to trek from the UES to see; and I was not let down. Â With only me and myself I didn't have an opportunity to try a wide array from the menu, but what I did have (1 Clark roll, 1pc. tuna, 1pc salmon) was wonderful. Â I find typically many sushi restaurants feature to much tempura, or sushi in razor thin slices, but this was not the case at Sushi Gallery. Â I had more than enough options from the sprawling Roll menu, and the sushi was quite thick, all for a reasonable price. Â The mom and pop reviews seemed to be right and the place did look right out of Tokyo, which I really appreciated. Â I look forward to my next visit soon regardless of the long journey!
we love sushi gallery! we make it something to look forward to and order from here every tuesday. it's quick, inexpensive, and fresh. our favorite is the black pepper roll and spicy combo!

Sashimi was good; rolls and service were less than stellar. One of the rolls was little more than a piece of cooked salmon atop a bit of sushi rice; not very flavorful, and it wasn't even cut. Maybe they forgot? Plus, we were told after our meal that they weren't accepting credit cards, even though their signage clearly indicates that they do. Keep looking...there's better sushi to be had

The food is very good here and reasonably priced. It is indeed a mom and pop shop, everything's very fresh, and the decor and atmosphere are lovely, including the music. It's my favorite sushi place in the neighborhood. The only reason I am giving it a 4 star rating is because once my udon soup came in a little too fishy. It was a delivery order, so I didn't change it. But I have eaten here multiple times and the quality was consistently high otherwise.

This is the cutest little place! Found it by accident one night and I'm so glad I decided to give it a try. They have really good rolls at very reasonable prices. Their miso soup is also really good. If you decide to stop by, try their New York roll! It's super yummy, it was by far my favorite! Definitely going there again.

Sushi Gallery is a very nice, cute spot located in the awesome Clark St station. Â As everyone else has stated, it has a sweet "mom & pop" vibe to it and the chefs/owners are very friendly and efficient with their work. Â I haven't dined in the place yet; I've only gotten takeout, but the sushi is always very fresh. Â I've been going here for a little over a year now and it seems to have gotten even better over time. Â The miso soup that you receive with your entrÃ©e is always hot and delicious. Â They always get your order right, and even if they're about to close at 11PM, they still happily answer the phone and take orders at or after 11, which is a rarity for Brooklyn Heights restaurants. Â Usually restaurants stop taking orders 15 to 30 minutes before their stated closing time, and most close at 10 sharp. Â I've had nothing but good experiences here and it will remain my convenient spot for those sushi cravings! Â Oh, and the prices here are remarkable for the quality and cuisine, especially as compared to Ozu across the street. Â It's also worth mentioning that Sushi Gallery is the only restaurant I've found in Brooklyn so far which has Korean items on its menu, and quite a few at that.

From the sidewalk, this place just looks gross: It's in the St. George Hotel, within spitting distance of a subway turmstile. And it's in Brooklyn Heights, where there seems to be an unwritten rule that Every Restaurant South of Cranberry Must Suck. This place doesn't. A long time resident of the Heights suggested I try it, and I was totally surprised. I've lived in the Heights for 8 years and would have sooner eaten an errant hot dog lying in a puddle of dog piss before getting sushi here. In fact, it's much better than Iron Chef, quieter, friendlier and comparably priced. It's easily the best sushi in the neighborhood.

Aftern living a block away for over a year, I finally tried Sushi Gallery over my wife's objections (subway sushi? Ick!) This is a lovely little Korean restaurant that serves the best sushi in Brooklyn Heights, vastly superior to any of its competitors. To do better, you'd have to venture to Hibino in Cobble Hill. The fish is consistently very fresh, and expertly prepared. The only reason they don't get 5 stars is that Â they stopped serving their delicious bibimbap and bulgogi, and they are sorely missed (though still on the menue for some reason) They do still serve my favorite Korean dish, Hwe Dup Bap, a sashimi salad with spicy sweet sesame paste. Don't be put off by the location - this is the real deal.

Their website and their voice mail say they open at noon, but their door sign says they open at 1:00. That's pretty late for trying to get lunch. I like their sushi, so today I went in at about 1:10. They told me they weren't open yet, and they wouldn't be open for another 20 to 30 minutes. It seems like a bad way to run a sushi restaurant when there are two other sushi places with good lunch deals directly across the street - Ozu and Iron Chef.

A little pearl in the rough. Wonderful tasty food prepared by sushi-mom and sushi-dad. They are so friendly and attentive that you just wanna stay. The decor is hideous but quite charming and it such a quiet place that me and my friends just hung out for 3 hours taking and feeling right at home! Once again the food is great and the taste is wonderful. Not a wild display of color and fancy Japanese flamboyant food magic, just real sushi and other delicious courses prepared with love and soul so that it taste lovely. Thank you!

Our favorite secret little sushi gem in Brooklyn Heights. Fish is ALWAYS super fresh and very delicious - have tried many rolls on the menu, all very well composed. The place is small and cute, very clean and has a very nice NY kind of feel to it. It's my sushi place to go to.

I tried this place bc the owner was very friendly whenever I walked by. I soon realized his friendliness is as limited as the seafood in his seafood soup. I ordered said soup with noodles specifically because i wanted seafood. When I asked what seafood was in there he couldn't really specify, but assured me it was a "bunch of different stuff." After waiting like 20 minutes, I finally got home, starving and excited only to find that after paying like 16 bucks, the "seafood" in my soup consisted of 3 mini mussels and one piece of calamari. I called Sushi Gallery and they were clearly annoyed. The owner wasted alot of time telling me noone has complained before. When I brought it back for a refund (would have been equally happy just to get some seafood added, but that didn't seem to be an option), they continued haranguing me, saying that the soup doesn't come with alot of seafood..for 16 bucks???? really?? They snatched the container, gave me attitude and a refund. Never again. Too many other sushi places like Ozu across the street (excellent service) to be bothered with that nonsense.

Wow... had solo lunch here and got the Gupo Gukbab and it was amazing. Everything I was craving. Soup was so flavorful, hearty, comforting. Banchan was perfectly seasoned. And it's so pretty and cozy inside. Service was super quick. Highly recommend. I'll be back :)

Stopped by for a quick lunch, got the galbi jjim and naengmyeon combo. Â As usual with Korean restaurants it came with a ton of banchan. Â Everything hit the spot. Â I recommend bringing a friend to share the experience with because the short rib is just that good!

I came here for lunch on a Tuesday afternoon with a friend. We both ordered the gamja tang (spicy pork bone soup with potatoes, perilla leaves, green onions, hot peppers, and perilla seeds). The panchan here were pretty good quality with pajeon (pancake), rice cakes, fish cake, etc. You can also request white or purple rice with your soup order. Definitely get the purple rice since it has pumpkin and beans. Plus purple rice is healthy and white rice is just empty carbs. The soup was very flavorful and they do give you large pork bones. I would come back, this place has pretty authentic Korean comfort food and the ingredients were definitely high quality.

Everything was so good! The ban Chan was delicious. The galbi Jim was so tender and flavorful and the cold noodles were a perfect combo. The bossam pork belly was very good as well. A great new addition to ktown!

I walked in on a Monday with a friend late afternoon ~2pm and we were the only customers. The service was great (probably cuz we were the only ones there) and I really enjoyed my Chueo Tang; I've never tasted mud fish nor perilla seed so I was intrigued and ordered it. Although the appearance of the soho is a bit muddy, it was delicious and flavorful (and fishy just as a fair warning for anyone thinking of ordering). I tried my friend's order of galbi + naengmyeon and it was good too!

Such a cozy restaurant with the most delicious Korean comfort food! I came here on a rainy Saturday night with a friend, and we decided to be bold and try all dishes we've never had before: moon snail salad, spicy cold noodles, spicy beef broth. We were blown away by all three dishes. Each was hearty and filling, with unique aromas and flavors. I will say, specifically, that the sullontang was divine: the meat was so tender it was falling off the bone, and the broth so rich that I found myself taking extra sips even after I was full. Additionally, in keeping with traditional Korean cuisine culture, we were served numerous delectable banchan as well to supplement our taste buds; and the water served was also the traditional Korean barley tea which I love so much. The waitresses were all friendly, and Lisa, the manager, was so lovely and kind. I'll definitely be back to share this place with other friends!

New trendy spot that popped up in Ktown which was pretty solid - my favorite was actually the skate fish which is an appetizer. They're known for their short rib, which was good but I think overpriced for the amount that you get.

I've been wanting to go here since I saw it opened and finally had a chance! We didn't have a res on a Wednesday night and had to wait around an hour for a table. I ordered the galbi jjim & mool naengmyeon combo - it's a litttle on the expensive side (price is better for lunch) but the serving sizes was pretty good and I definitely walked away pretty fool! The galbi jjim was super tender and flavorful - good level of sweetness. The mool naengmyeon was also super yummy and cold & refreshing. My friend got the gamja tang which was decent and was a large portion - I personally liked the galbi jjim better than this. You also get free banchan including some fish cakes and jeon and they were pretty yummy as well! This is a great addition to the ktown area, and I'd definitely go back! The food was good and the ambience is nice as well.

Very authentic Korean restaurant in midtown manhattan. The side dishes were super yummy and the ambiance of the restaurant was warm and cozy. Service was amazing and everyone was super friendly. Have so many banchan refills!!! The meat was super tender and has a kick of warm spice but it wasn't super spicy. Came with rice too- we chose purple rice!!

Big space with authentic Korean dishes. Great for big group catch ups. I would say it was a bit overpriced for the portion sizes. Like we literally got 5 things and it was around $250 (with tip). Idk to me there are better places in terms of quality and value. But!!! everything came with SOOO many side dishes which was really really nice. There were some really delicious and surprising side dishes too like fish cake and Korean pancake. Servers were all very nice and attentive. Highly recommend getting the galbi and the galbi fried rice.

Worth trying! We had the large galbijim between three people and there was a good portion of meat and it was flavorful! We added the cold noodle and the fried rice and I would recommend doing so too! Even during the winter months, the cold noodle is refreshing and delicious. We also liked the banchan and it comes with Korean pancakes and kimchi.

A new place just opened near ktown and the owner was also very nice. Â This is authentic Korean food. All the dishes are exactly what you are craving for during a cold windy day. Every side dish was delicious and healthy, and my favorite was their seafood pancake. The main entries were huge portions and reasonably priced. Once you made the order, they all came out like after 5 mins. Super efficient! Will def come back to try their dinner menu.
Definitely check out this newer Korean restaurant in ktown. The spicy pork bone soup is so good and perfect for the winter. Very cozy ambiance.

I've been to countless Korean restaurants in NYC and can say that Olle was certainly memorable! Very modern interior, we came here with a group of 6 without a reservation and were seated promptly. May need a reservation as the restaurant was busy but we were lucky! The banchan was some of my favorite, and all the food was incredibly flavorful. We cleaned up every plate, it was delicious!
I can't overstate what a great time I had. The food is top three experiences of my life. The service was excellent and the ambiance was perfect. Don't hesitate; just come.

Solid Korean spot located a few blocks away from the K-Town madness. Their sullungtang is the perfect dish for a cold winter's day - the broth is phenomenal by itself and comes served with plenty of scallions (my favorite) but can be seasoned to your liking with fresh salt and peppers, and they don't skimp on the beef! The banchan here is also the best set of banchan you can find in the city - kimchi, spicy pickled radish, scallion pancake (!!), marinated sliced onions and marinated hard boiled egg. Will definitely be coming back.

I was recommended this place for their Gamjatang and it's pretty good. My favorite so far is the Mul-Naengmyeon though. I ordered this as part of the "Galbi + Naengmyeon" option on the menu but the galbi was disappointing. The meat seemed a bit dried out and hard to chew on. The Mul-Naengmyeon was 10/10 though. The broth was so good that I didn't have to add any vinegar, which people usually do to give it better flavor. Not sure whether the galbi is that bad for the main menu since it is one of their popular dishes. It was probably just bad for the mini dish so I know not to order that "Galbi + Naengmyeon" combo next time.

I was craving Galbi Jjim and gamjatang while in NYC and I found this gem! This is a new modern, luxurious looking Korean restaurant! I came here for lunch when they opened so there wasn't a wait. The staff was also friendly! We ordered the galbi + naengmyeon (mini ver. of the Galbi jjim if you just want to try it! It was so flavorful and tender! It had a more herbal essence to it than other Galbi Jjim I've had. The naengmyeon was refreshing and yummy!) and the gamjatang (I was surprised how big the portion was! I couldn't finish the whole thing! It was so tasty. I do think I've had better gamjatang at other places but this definitely satisfied my craving! Perfect for a cold day as well!) I definitely think the price is worth for the portions you get! I definitely recommend trying this place out!

Really busy and loud place in the center of Manhattan. We came here for a late lunch and were able to get seated within 10 minutes. They have two floors of seating, and we were seated on the first floor, but we'd definitely recommend asking to sit on the second floor as the music is a lot less loud and it's much less crowded. We ordered one of the most popular dish, Galbi Jjim (marinated short rib) and Mool Naengmyeon (Korean Cold noodles). You can get the Bibim Naengmyeon if you want, it is the spicy version of Naengmyeon. It comes with lots of different side dishes. Their kimchi is also very good!

A great new spot by ktown! This place is pretty busy so be sure to snag a reservation beforehand. My friend and I got seated right away. I would say the tables are a little small but maybe we ordered a lot of food lol we got the galbijjim and cold noodles combo as well as the gamjatang stew. The gamjatang stew is good but hard to eat at a restaurant around the pork bones. This place is on the pricier end for Korean food but the portion sizes were decent and everything was so tasty. It was PLENTY for 2 people and we had leftovers to take home.

Food was really good, one of the banchans was green onion pancake which no restaurant I've ever been to serves as banchan! We got both cold noodles and the flavor was refreshing and yummy, would be perfect in the summer when it's hot and humid. The bossam, I would skip on as it's nothing special. The sullongtang was just like any other place. The galbi jjim was really tender and had a lot of flavor, definitely recommend ordering the option to into fried rice after. The Won Mae Plum liqueur was absolutely delicious, I would skip on the Red Monkey Makgeolli as it had no flavor other than regular rice wine.

The decor in here is so beautiful and rustic. The plates and utensils were so pretty. Service and time of arrival of food was great- we had the galbi and spicy cold noodle along with soulongtong! I enjoy the flavors of galbi and the cold noodles.

Their signature dish, the galbi Jim (braised short rib with pepper and mushroom) was delicious, but kind of overpriced for what it is. The dish is $70 for the small, which I'd say feeds 2, but you also want to order other things or at least get rice on the side to be full. I did love that they served bori cha (barley tea) instead of water! I might want to come back and try the soups, but with so many amazing Korean restaurants in the area, I'd say personally Olle is worth one visit, but there's no need to come back.

Randomly came here on a whim when Okdongsik next door was full. Â Surprisingly, the food was fairly decent for NYC Korean food. Â The ambience, vibe, and service was great. Â They serve a somewhat deconstructed Bibimbap which was interesting as you get to remove items you may not like before you add them to the bowl rather than have to pick through them yourself. Â The barchan and soup were great and refreshing. Â Overall, a solid choice, I would return.

Lovely Korean dinner away from the bustle of Koreatown. Olle is a surprisingly quiet, intimate restaurant with great food to share. We got a bulgogi jongul, skate fish app, galbi jjim and an oyster soup to share. We also added on the small bibim naemyeon. It was more than plenty for 7 people. Everything was good and tasted very authentic and carefully made. The service was attentive and they have a really good, red colored makgeolli. The galbijjim is probably the must order dish here, and the bibim cold noodles that accompanied it was excellent as well. Try this place!
Really great dining experience! Highly recommend the galbijim and naengmyun. Side dishes were great too
GREAT food - amazing staff. Was an incredible meal and experience - loved it. If you are unsure of that to order just ask the staff - they were great at helping choose.

Our group (3 girls) went to Olle on Saturday night and got the Galbi Jjim and each of us ordered a small nengmyun. During the meal we decided to also add on the fried rice but was then told by our server that we couldn't add the fried rice because we had already ordered 2 noodle sides and are not allowed to order another (even though we had 3 noodle dishes?). This was confusing since nothing is written on their menu and our server hadn't mentioned this when we ordered. The service was slow and confusing, the portions were very small and while the flavors were good it wasn't worth it. They definitely need to train their servers better and provide more explanation on their menu. If you're in ktown, there are definitely better places to eat dinner.
completely authentic!!!!! Â  very good! Â grest flavors! great service! Â nice restaurant! â¼â¼â¼â¼â¼
Highly recommend the gamja tang and fermented skate fish, extremely comforting food with great portions.

Loved my dinner experience at Olle. Their dinnerware was beautiful and the food was so great! This is not your typical Korean bbq spot, but their braised short rib is delicious! It has a little kick so if you're planning to go with little children, please note that braised short ribs can be spicy for the little ones. We ordered small gooksoo and nengmyun as well as the fried rice at the end. All very tasty! Can't wait to go back and try more dishes!
Got the gamja tang and it was terrible - no salt, the meat tasted very overcooked and didn't have any flavor seeped in (not surprised because the soup itself was flavorless)
Great food service and ambiance. We also enjoyed the craft beers! Highly recommend this place. Stopped by on Christmas Day

Authentic Korean food has always been hard to find in Manhattan but Olle is a new oasis for anyone looking for a meal that makes you feel like you are eating your mom's food at home. Made with high-quality ingredients and prepared in a meticulous fashion without shortcuts, the food is excellent and this cozy yet elevated restaurant stands out among the sea of new Korean/Korean fusion spots which are good for a meal but rarely warrant a second visit. Will definitely be back here to try the rest of the menu.
Great food, cute dishes, and super kind and attentive service. Definitely seems like a great place for plenty of occasions!
This place is one of my new favorite spots. Great energy, great food, and of course great drinks! The food is unreal and perfect for the atmosphere.
Amazing food / vibes at the delicious Mexico City-inspired bar and restaurant. Highly recommend getting everything, including the tuna tostada, quesadilla, chicharrones and Mexican pizza.

I stopped by on opening night with some friends. Great music and vibe with an interesting take on Mexican food. The menu is pretty limited but some standouts included the chicken tacos (loved the smoky flavors!) and the wings which were very tangy from the tamarind. We also tried the mezcal flight which was delicious and perfect for sharing. They said they will rotate mezcals monthly so I'm excited to come back to try other producers. The cocktail list is extensive and perfect if you like mezcal based drinks. The only thing missing was a dessert menu.

I got a delicious Paloma cocktail that went very refreshingly with our guacamole. I also the mushroom quesadillas, which were satisfying but not as tasty as the dipping sauce that came with it. My boyfriend got the chicken sandwich, which I sampled. It had a much darker and earthier flavor for the meat than I expected, but it made a complex complement to the zing of the sauce. The restaurant was pretty loud but also cheerful and lively and a good addition to the neighborhood.

The food was so yummy and comforting. I really liked the onion fritters, super similar to south Asian pakoras. The ambience was even better , such a nice place to catch up with friends and it wasn't too busy the day I went so it felt more intimate. The drinks and food were brought out promptly and service was great. Definitely recommend the tamarind drink

Just finished eating Tea Leaf Salad, coconut rice, mango salad and garlic noodles. We couldn't finish it because it was too salty and had a weird after taste. Will not order here again. So disappointed.

I've reviewed this restaurant before, but not for a delivery order. The delivery of the food was fast and seamless. I'm taking one start off due to the small portions of the white rice, coconut rice ($4), and chicken curry ($23). I've included photos so you can be the judge. The portion size of the onion fritters ($12), lemongrass fish noodle soup ($18), and tea leaf salad ($16) were all spot on. I'll forever keep coming back for the tea leaf salad which never disappoints. Everything else was delicious too! Prices listed are delivery from DoorDash.

It's hard to find a Burmese restaurant in New York (why is that?), so when my friend suggested this spot I was down to try it! Â I frequent the popular Burma Superstar in San Francisco every time I go back home, and compared to that restaurant the Tea Leaf Salad ($16) was sub-par. Â It would have been nice if they mixed the salad at the table, and the actual tea leaf portion was small. Â The staff was nice - the place gives off a very hippie Brooklyn feel. Â After the Tea Lead Salad was served it seemed like we waited 35+ minutes for the next dish to come out. Â We ordered the Spicy Pork Shoulder Slaw ($17) that had probably 4 pieces of actual pork in there, Spicy Mee Shay Noodle ($18 + $4 for pork) - best dish we had in my opinion, Pork in Tea Leaf Curry ($26) and the Spicy Masala Beef ($25). Â We also ordered the Going Places IPA Beer from Hopewell Brewing Co. ($10 - why is this can expensive where I can buy it at the store for more than half price cheaper?) but got served a different brewery's beer. Â The heads up on the change of beer would've been nice! Â The two curries we had were a bit disappointing, especially for the price. Â The pork and ground beef were dry and tasteless. Â We expected more from the beef (also wasn't expecting it to be ground beef even though we saw later it said so on the menu) and the portion for it was so small for the price the charge for it. Â Whatever orange sauce they had on the side was extremely salty. Â Overall I don't think I'll be coming back to dine here :/

My review is more related to the food delivery experience I had from Rangoon. I ordered the Spicy Beef Masala, Prawn Curry and Fried Chicken Bites, and was very disappointed in the portion sizes. I've eaten there in person before, and the servings were about half the size you normally get in person eating there. Additionally, they forgot to put the curry in my delivery order so I ended up just getting a tray of prawns (still in the shell). The food was decent but definitely much better in person. DO NOT ORDER FROM RANGOON FOR HOME DELIVERY.
I really wanted to like the place, but wasn't to my liking. Dishes feel a little one dimensional, not very spicy. Wouldn't recommend to a friend.

I was visiting family in Brooklyn this weekend and my daughter said I just had to try this Burmese restaurant on Park Place. I'm so glad I did. For my starter I ordered the Tea Leaf Salad. It consisted of Burmese fermented tea leaves, peanuts, fried beans, toasted seeds and lime juice. It was crunchy and had flavors I've never had all combined in one dish. It was amazing. For my appetizer I ordered the Onion Fritter. It was made with potato and onions and was also gluten-free. The dipping sauce was tamarind and garlic. It had such unique flavors my description will not do it any Justice. Â It was the perfect amount of crunchy. I could have stopped there but I just wanted to order one of everything on that menu! I finally decided on the Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup. The broth was seared to perfection. It was adorned by coconut shreds, red onions and topped with an egg that was mildly cooked. Â I washed it all down with a 16oz Sparkling Water, although, there were many drinks to choose from. I wish I would've had room for the tapioca. If you live or visit New York, make sure you treat yourself to this wonderful place. I was even able to meet the Chef, Pablo. He came out after every dish and made sure I was happy! I went to eat at several places while on my trip, and this was definitely my fave!
My lychee cocktail was good but, like many others have said, all of the food just tasted like a lot of salt. Service was friendly and attentive.
Fun and interesting food with good decor. Cool cocktails. But nothing was blow your mind delicious

It pains me to give a place like this so few stars, but I was really underwhelmed - especially how excited I was about getting some underserved Burmese food. The space is clean, very white, hip-ish looking. But the food fell flat - far from bad, but further from anything special.
I've had Burmese food in SF and liked it so much better. Â My husband ordered 2 noodle soups and both were bland. Â No flavor at all. Â Fish sauce / chili did not help! Â Will not be returning.
Food was shockingly bad. No flavor, items missing from things we ordered (chicken and squash had no squash in it) and seemed like maybe something went wrong in the kitchen.

Foods was great, very little for the price. Very dark for my taste. I was expecting nice instrumental Japanise music or nice Jazz. I felt the music didn't go with the food or the atmosphere. So, it was ok, not for me.

Really enjoyed Rangoon! Giving this place four stars only because the service was slow, but it was a Saturday night so that's understandable. We would've ordered more drinks and tried to get the waitress' attention several times but wound up giving up. However, the decor was beautiful--we sat outside and enjoyed the setup; there are string lights, curtains to separate dining parties, and flowers. For our meals, we started with the onion fritters (one of our favorite items), and the tea leaf salad. For mains, my partner had the chicken curry and devoured every last bite; I got the garlic noodles with shrimp--also amazing, and because there was such a generous portion, I took what I couldn't eat to go. Drink-wise, I had the Kayay Lan, which is a mix of Prosecco and lychee -- amazing! My partner started with the Nhint Ko Tu but switched over to the Kayay Lan. All in all this is a really unique place and I'll bring my friend here when she comes to visit. I'll try to go on a less busy night.

The food was delicious - shrimp curry and spicy pork udon noodles. The servers were kind and not too over the top. However, 4 stars because the outdoor ambiance could use some help to match the level of the food - add some plants and maybe upgrade table and chairs to make it more comfortable and welcoming. The outside place reminds us of early emergency Covid days - so time to step up and embrace your outdoor space! I hope the next time we visit (and we will be back) to see this.

I ordered the spicy noodles with pork, and it tasted overly sour/tangy, I didn't taste much spice at all. Ironically, the added pork did not have much flavor at all and the texture reminded me of overly boiled pork.

Lovely design. Pretty bad food. The onion fritters were like lead and not freshly made. The tea salad okay but it too was soggy and seemed made another day. The garlic noodles were mostly noodles and soy sauce. Was there a Malaysian in the kitchen? Lovely waitress.

I was excited to try this place when I found it on Yelp. My favorite Burmese place had closed down so I've been missing the cuisine. The restaurant does have outdoor seating which looked really cute but I opted to take my order to go. To clarify any misunderstandings, I was there in person to order and pick up the food! The Interior was pristine and the staff was very friendly when I ordered. I ordered the Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup and a Lemon Grass Fish Noodle Soup for my boyfriend, two staple dishes in Burmese cuisine! The food smelled amazing, but the taste didn't match up. My dish was okay; the coconut soup was a little grainy and needed a little more seasoning. My boyfriend enjoyed the first few bites of his dish but he said it also lacked flavor. Perhaps the other dishes will be better, but I'm not sure that I'd go back as the dishes were a bit pricey too.

This place is okay. After having the tea leaf salad at Burma superstar in San Francisco, the one here is less flavorful and kind of disappointing. I also got the tamarind pumpkin stew which was tasty but also wasn't very different from a dal (Indian lentil curry). Also everything in the stew was very soft except for the pumpkin (kabocha squash) which was still a little hard with a slight crunch - kind of a jarring texture in the stew. I would have preferred it to be much cooked more. My fiancÃ© loooove his meat dish though so maybe a good place for non-vegetarians. Outdoor seating area is nice though- they have a garden in the back away from the street bustle & tables are covered from rain.

Sat in the lovely, big, dare I say romantic back yard area. Each table very cutely curtained off from the others so it was a nice private dining experience - perfect for a date or a dinner where maybe you want to actually hear what your friends are saying. The wine and beer list is the most impressive I've seen from a restaurant, or bar for that matter, in a while. Nice selection of orange wines, the two we tried were excellently weird, perfect for summer, perfectly paired with the appetizer salads, and the waiter made a recommendation for a bottle of chilled red which was even better. As for appetizers, the tea leaf salad is a refreshing, healthy must try and the onion fritters are a not so healthy but totally worth it must try. Their texture and taste exceeds even what you think they will taste by looking at them like and the sauce that comes with them I wanted to bottle up and put on everything. The pork salad sounds like an oxymoron but it is also refreshing, light, and full of flavors for your bored palate. And for dinner, I had to try the mohinga lemongrass fish soup with noodle (and onion fritter!) which I will definitely be coming back for, and my friends got the tamarind pumpkin stew, the braised pork in banana leaf, and the chicken soup. The noodles and taste of the chicken soup were absolutely heartwarming, as was the pumpkin stew which seemed like a really nice option for those trying to stay healthy. We also got the crispy anchovies (with nice big chunks of crispy garlic!) and fish relish sides, which if you're a fish freak like me you must get. Also. Get the coconut rice. Get a couple of orders of it. The staff is really friendly and dare I say really fashionable and also knowledgeable about the cuisine. Overall, come hungry, come thirsty, and don't come expecting Thai, or Chinese or whatever the heck you're expecting. If you aren't familiar with Burmese food, be prepared to be lead on a delicious new adventure that will feature flavors you are familiar with and didn't expect, and flavors you've never tasted before. I wish I had more pictures of the entrees but the orange wine was getting to me by then and they were coming out a little blurry...

I came here on a date night and the food was great. But what made the experience was our server. Raphaellla was amazing! She was so friendly welcoming and knowledgeable. Overall best date night we have had in awhile thanks to Raphis!!

The best part of the meal was the beer, and even that was served in a warm glass. The spicy udon had no flavor, only salt. The prawn curry broth was undercooked, underseasoned. Wanted to like the place but won't be coming back.
As the other reviews alluded to, the bland and underwhelming food is not worth the pricy $25+ small entrees. Stay away!

Amazing food. I am from Bengal in India so have a lot of similarities in the style of food. We ordered the following - Â Braised Pork Curry, Coconut Chicken Noodle Soup Onion Fritters and Rangoon chicken Curry. The two curries were amazing and the onion fritters were on point. Felt disappointed by the coconut chicken noodle soup - it was bland. So slight blemish in the otherwise perfect experience. Will be going back soon - loved the food.
